text: From your example, it seems to me you want to use a static method.

code:
class mystuff:
  @staticmethod
  def average(a,b,c): #get the average of three numbers
    result=a+b+c
    result=result/3
    return result

print mystuff.average(9,18,27)

text: Please note that an heavy usage of static methods in python is usually a symptom of some bad smell - if you really need functions, then declare them directly on module level.
You can instantiate the class by declaring a variable and calling the class as if it were a function:
However, this won't work with the code you gave us.
When you call a class method on a given object (x), it always passes a pointer to the object as the first parameter when it calls the function.
So if you run your code right now, you'll see this error message:

code: TypeError: average() takes exactly 3 arguments (4 given)

text: To fix this, you'll need to modify the definition of the average method to take four parameters.
The first parameter is an object reference, and the remaining 3 parameters would be for the 3 numbers.
